elements.text: SYLVESTER McCOY Time traveller.
TRACEY CHILDS A time-travelling Nazi physicist and physician who hates the Doctor for destroying her future.
SYLVIA O’DONNELL: ANN BELL
A formidable woman who used to party with the Mitfords, when she was younger. She holds... strong opinions on most subjects.
ABIGAIL McKERN Flighty and homely. She imagines Kenya to be a suburb of the Home Counties.
JOANNAH TINCEY Teenaged, more used to riding horses and playing tennis than fighting the Mau Mau.
ALEX MALLINSON
An alien mule, a workhorse for the Chaelis. He cannot speak, and his character has been submerged by the Chaelis’s control.
CHUK IWUJI A Kenyan farm worker who has joined the Mau Mau and intends taking his country back from the British.
THE CAST A group mind consisting of a flock of small humming-birds.
ALEX MALLINSON Very formal, clipped pronunciation.
Doctor Who — A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 2 of 133
LISA BOWERMAN
DAVID RICHARDSON
NICHOLAS BRIGGS & JASON HAIGH-ELLERY

Doctor Who — A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 3 of 133
WHO —- A THOUSAND TINY WINGS
EPISODE ONE
FX: THEME MUSIC
SCENE 1: SITTING ROOM
(FX: WE START WITH THE SOUND OF THE JUNGLE - PARROTS SQUAWKING, MONKEYS CHATTERING, THE OCCASIONAL ROAR OF A
ANIMAL)
(SOFTLY, IN THE BACKGROUND, IS THE SOUND OF MUSIC - A SCOTT
RAG, BUT NOT ‘THE ENTERTAINER’, PLEASE — PLAYING ON A CRACKLY RADIO’. THE MUSIC GETS LOUDER, AND THE JUNGLE
QUIETER, AS IF WE ARE MOVING TOWARDS THE SOURCE OF THE MUSIC)
(FADE OUT THE SOUNDS OF THE JUNGLE. WE CAN HEAR THE MUSIC
NOW, AND WE CAN ALSO HEAR THE SOUND OF A TYPEWRITER)
O’ DONNELL (MIDDLE-AGED, USED TO BEING OBEYED) Lucy, dear, could you stop for a moment?
FX: THE TYPEWRITER STOPS
WATTS (YOUNG, EAGER TO PLEASE) Sorry, Mrs O’Donnell, was I disturbing you?
No. (BEAT) I just thought I heard something. Gunfire. Or cars. (BEAT) I must have been imagining it.
Perhaps it’s on the radio?
(FX: THE VOLUME OF THE MUSIC DIMINISHES AS SHE TURNS IT DOWN. THERE IS A CLICK, AND IT STOPS ALTOGETHER) .
[AUTHOR’S NOTE: THE MUSIC ITSELF SHOULD BE OUT OF COPYRIGHT, AS IT WAS
AROUND 1899, SO THE PERFORMANCE IS THE ONLY THING TO BE
OF. IF NECESSARY, GET SOMEONE TO PLAY IT ESPECIALLY FOR THE RECORDING. ALTERNATIVELY, THERE IS A RECORDING OF JOPLIN HIMSELF
HIS MUSIC ON A PIANO ROLL THAT SHOULD BE ENTIRELY OUT OF COPYRIGHT]
Doctor Who — A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 4 of 133
There. Can you here anything now?
(TARTLY) No, but I don’t think the composer ever considered using the sound of gunfire as an accompaniment to his music.
Tchaikovsky used cannons in the Eighteen Twelve Overture.

Tchaikovsky was a musical genius, and besides, he was writing about the defence of Moscow against Napoleon’s army. It’s difficult to write music about a war without incorporating some kind of reference to violence. Mr Scott Joplin, on the other hand, is a competent tinkerer who wrote disposable tunes for the masses.
You used to like it when they played Joplin at the Nairobi Tennis Club. You used to say you wanted to hear more.
I don’t believe I ever said that.
I remember Mr O’Donnell bought England, the last time he went. then put it away.
an LP back with him from You played it once, and
You are very young, Lucy. You have a lot to learn.
BEAT
I wonder if anyone will write a symphony about this revolution.
(FIRMLY) This is not a revolution. This is a tawdry uprising on the part of some discontented natives who don’t know when they’re well off.
Doctor Who — A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 5 of 133
Even so... It’s been a fortnight now. You would think that things would have calmed down. You would think we would have heard something.
The British Government will not let this situation go on for long. They will send the troops in, and everything will go back to the way it was.
(HUSHED) Sometimes I wonder if we’re the only white people left in Kenya.

(SHARPLY) Don’t be foolish, girl. Yes, the natives have cut the lines of communication, and taken control of a few Government buildings, but my husband and your father and veryone else are fighting back. Now, you go back to your letter, or whatever it is, and don’t worry about it.
(FX: THE TYPING STARTS AGAIN, TENTATIVE AT FIRST BUT THEN
STRONGER)
I’m writing to my father, letting him know how I am, and where I am.
There’s no post. You know that, don’t you?
Someone might pass by on their way to Nairobi. They could take the letter. (SLIGHTLY PANICKED) Daddy won’t know where to find me otherwise. It’s not like this is our farmhouse.
It was fortunate that we found it.
FX: DINNER GONG BEING HIT. THE TYPEWRITER STOPS
WATERFORD (OUTSIDE THE ROOM, CALLING) Elizabeth? Christine? Lunch is nearly ready.
Doctor Who — A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 6 of 133
(IN DISTANCE, ALMOST UNRECOGNISABLE) Coming!
FX: WE HEAR DENISE WATERFORD MOVE INTO THE ROOM

(THIRTYISH AND ALWAYS SLIGHTLY BREATHLESS) Hello Sylvia, hello Lucy. You heard the gong, I assume, so I won’t bang it again. Lunch isn’t much, I’m afraid. More tinned rations, and some sweet potatoes from the garden.
I’m sure it will be wonderful. (BEAT) How are the supplies holding up?
Oh, we’re managing. Christine eats like a bird anyway, and poor Lucy can’t keep anything down.
Still feeling rough, Lucy?
(APOLOGETIC) Running a bit of a temperature, I’m afraid.
You look a trifle flushed. You should get Elizabeth to take a look at you.
I already did. She said she thought it was just a touch of gyppy tummy. That and, you know... (EMBARASSED) ...the
stress of waiting, and not knowing about what’s happened to my family. She’s given me some powders.
We were lucky Elizabeth ended up here at the farm. I don’t know who better we could have hoped for than a doctor - (SOTTO VOCE) except perhaps a good pastry chef.
Have either of you seen Christine today? She didn’t answer just now.
Doctor Who — A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 7 of 133
She went for a lie down after breakfast. (CONSPIRATORIALLY) I think she’s got a touch of gyppy tummy too.
FX: SOUND OF SOMEONE COMING DOWN THE STAIRS
(FROM OUTSIDE; RECOGNISABLY KLEIN NOW) I hope you didn’t start without me. Any news on the radio?

To date, the BBC World Service has been remarkably quiet about the Mau Mau uprising. They seem much more interested in the music of Scott Joplin. (BITTERLY) I blame the Prime Minister. Winston Churchill had no business taking Britain into the Second World War, and he’s a senile old fool now. I sometimes wonder if he’1l have the stomach to act against the rebels.
(AGHAST) You mean you think the Army’s not coming?
(SUDDENLY TIRED) I don’t know what I’m saying. I’m tired and I’m worried and I’m sick of listening out for the sound of gunfire. I just want it all to be over.
FX: KLEIN WALKS ACROSS TO THE WINDOW
FX: THE WINDOW SASH IS RAISED
I hate to sound like a cliché, but it’s quiet out there.
Too quiet.
Better that than the alternative.
Can you see anything, Elizabeth?
Nothing moving, apart from the breeze in the trees. The sky’s clouding over. I think we’re in for a storm.
Too early in the season for a storm.
Doctor Who — A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 8 of 133
I’ve been wondering - was this house built in a natural clearing, or did the owners deliberately cut down the jungle around it?
A little of both, I suspect.
I’ve been trying to remember who did own this farm.
But I’d feel a lot happier if we could see the fence, or the main gates. I worry that the natives will get in without us knowing, and the first we’ll know about it is
when we see them coming around a bend in the driveway, waving their guns.
I think it was the Braithwaites. Maude and Harold.
There are rifles or shotguns beside every window, upstairs and down, and Lucy and I have been checking every quarter hour.
Or the Thorneycrofts, perhaps.
I’ve been doing upstairs and Sylvia’s been doing downstairs.
(FX: SOUND OF A RIFLE BEING LIFTED AND THE BOLT DRAWN BACK, THEN CLOSED AGAIN)
I see someone knows their way around a rifle.
So do you, apparently. (BEAT) My husband taught me to shoot when we first arrived in Kenya.
Doctor Who — A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 9 of 133
How very practical of him. (BEAT) Could you shoot a person? A man?
Oh yes.
Perhaps we ought to set up a rota. Let each of us take a turn at the windows, upstairs and down.
Yes; 1 think @t was. the TRorneycrorts:, (BEAT) Don’t you think a rota is a little, well, officious? I mean, this isn’t Nazi Germany, is it?
(LEVEL) No. If it was, the natives wouldn’t be allowed to revolt.
Well said.
I tell you what - I’11l pop upstairs and do a tour round the windows before we have lunch.
Are you sure you’re feeling up to it?
Those powders you gave me helped settle my stomach.
Good girl.
Check in on Christine. She shouldn’t be still asleep.
FX: LUCY LEAVES
(GRIMLY) Perhaps we ought to be setting up shifts. Two people asleep and three awake all the time, one on continuous sentry duty. That way we can’t be taken by surprise at night.
Doctor Who - A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 10 of 133
Only three of us awake at any time? How could we play Bridge then?
Denise, my dear, I rather think we have bigger concerns than getting a four for Bridge.

(STIFFLY) I know there’s a revolution going on, but I don’t think we should let that be an excuse for letting our standards slip. We are British, after all. (BEAT) And talking of which, I’1l go and serve lunch up. Where are the servants when you need them?
FX: DENISE LEAVES
Outside, setting fire to things, I think you’ll find.
Ah, the British Empire at its glorious best.
A trifle bitter, there, Doctor Klein?
Not bitter. Just... regretful.
Regretting what, exactly?
Things that might have been.
Germany is a very progressive country, it seems to me. Always looking to the future. Just look at how you were allowed to become a doctor. You wouldn’t find that kind of
thing happening in Britain.
Have you been to Germany, Mrs O’ Donnell?
(CAREFULLY) My husband is German. We met in Munich in Nineteen Thirty Three.
Doctor Who -— A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 11 of 133
That must have been... awkward. Later.
Yes. (BEAT) O’Donnell is not my married name. Heinrich feels that we. should: use my surname: rather than his, Even now.
Very wise.
FADE OUT
Doctor Who — A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 12 of 133
SCENE 2: UPSTAIRS HALL
(FX: THE STAIRS LEADING UP TO THE FIRST FLOOR. LUCY IS
BRIGHTLY UP THEM. HER FOOTSTEPS REACH THE LANDING, AND SLOW AS SHE NEARS A PARTICULAR DOOR)
FX: A DISCREET KNOCK
Mrs MacCormack? Are you awake?
FX: MORE KNOCKING, LOUDER THIS TIME
Christine, it’s Lucy. It’s nearly lunchtime!
BEAT
Well, I’1ll make sure they leave a plate for you in the oven, to keep warm.
(FX: A FLUTTERING, WHIRRING SOUND BEHIND THE DOOR, LIKE SCRAPS OF PAPER BEING THROWN INTO THE PATH OF A FAN)
Mrs MacCormack, is that you?
FX: MORE FLUTTERING, LOUDER AND MORE INSISTENT
Are you alright?
FX: THE SOUND FADES AWAY
(UNSURE) Christine? (BEAT) I’11 get Doctor Klein.
FADE OUT
Doctor Who -— A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 13 of 133
SCENE 3: DINING ROOM
(FX: FADE TO THE DINING ROOM. THE SOUND OF CUTLERY CLINKING ON PLATES)
FX: LUCY ENTERS
Oh, you started without me!
We did wait, but the food was going cold, and you were taking so long!
How is Mrs MacCormack?
I think she’s still asleep, but...
But what, child?
I thought I heard something in her room.
(PANICKED) An intruder?
No. At least, I don’t think so. More like a fluttering, as if there was a bird trapped in there.
Don’t be fanciful. Christine wouldn’t have opened her windows, and even if she did I can’t imagine a bird flying inside.
Maybe she’s ill.
I’1ll check in on her after lunch, but I’m sure she’s alright.
But what about that noise?
Doctor Who — A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 14 of 133
It was the wind, playing tricks.
Did you check the rest of the windows?
All the ones I could get to. There’s nothing out there but the jungle, and the clearing, and the animals. And the storm clouds.
Storm clouds? It’s not the rainy season yet, surely?
(FX: THE DISTANT SOUND OF THE TARDIS, LANDING, OUTSIDE IN THE JUNGLE)
FX: A CUP IS DROPPED, AND SHATTERS
Elizabeth, are you all right? It’s just thunder.
(HALF IN SHOCK) Just thunder. Yes, of course it is. Sorry. Just had a dizzy turn.
Even the weather is rising up against us.
We should close the storm shutters.
If we do that we won’t be able to spot when the natives attack.
(SCARED) When?
Tt.
I think it might be worth doing a tour of the boundary fence later. Just to check that there aren’t any breaks.
Doctor Who - A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 15 of 133
I’1ll go. I could do with a walk.
I’1l go with you.
Can you handle a gun?
(PRIMLY) I’m sure it can’t be that hard.
FX: FADE OUT LUNCH
FX: TIME PASSES
Doctor Who -— A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 16 of 133
SCENE 4: THE RAINFOREST
(FADE UP JUNGLE SOUNDS AND THE SOUND OF FOOTSTEPS ON EARTH AND LEAVES BEING BRUSHED ASIDE)
Well, this stretch is still intact. We must have covered half the boundary by now.
(BREATHLESS) Only half? It feels like we’ve been walking for hours.
You should play more tennis at the club.
I look forward to the time when I can.
So far I’ve not seen any breaks in the fence, or any signs that the Mau Mau are getting close. What about you?
I thought I saw smoke on the horizon earlier, but it might just have been heat haze. (SUDDENLY) Oh damn this place! Why can’t things just go back to the way they were? We

were happy. The natives were happy. At least, they always seemed that way. If they wanted to be treated differently they could have just told us, couldn’t they? There was no need for all this fighting and burning buildings.
All they’ve done is to prove they’re not grown up enough to run their own affairs. They’re like children. They need us to look after them. (BEAT) I think it’s time to move
on to the next section. Another hour or so should see us finished. And then I suggest we repair back to the house and settle into a couple of well-deserved gin-and-tonics.
NO REACTION FROM DENISE
(FX: DISTANTLY, A FLUTTERING, WHIRRING SOUND, AS BEFORE IN THE HOUSE)
Denise? What’s the matter?
Doctor Who - A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 17 of 133
I thought... I thought I saw something moving, through the trees over there.
FX: THE SAFETY CATCH ON A RIFLE BEING RELEASED
(SHARPLY) A person?
I’m not sure. I just saw a flash of colour. Turquoise, and iridescent, like silk.
(SCORNFUL) You saw someone wearing a blue silk dress in the middle of the rainforest? Let’s hope they can play bridge as well.
I didn’t see a person. It was more like... leaves caught in a sudden flurry of wind. Blue leaves, or petals, or something - spinning. And then it was gone.
No gin-and-tonic for you when we get back.
I’m going over to take a look.
I’l1l cover you from here. No sense in us both going.
FX: SOUND OF SOMEONE MOVING AWAY, THROUGH THE TREES
Anything?
(DISTANT, SHOCKED) Oh my good Lord!
What is it?
Come and look!
Doctor Who —- A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 18 of 133
(FX: WE MOVE WITH SYLVIA TOWARDS WHERE DENISE IS. AS WE DO SO, DENISE’S VOICE GETS LOUDER)
(FLUSTERED) I thought at first it was just a fallen tree trunk, but it’s not. It’s a body, covered in blood.
(PRACTICAL) A native, do you think?
It must be.
So thin! Look at its knees and elbows. They’re swollen like turnips.
It’s malnourished!
There’s something not right about this. I’m no doctor, but surely legs and arms bend in the middle, not there.
(INCREDULOUS) And look - there’s another joint!
It’s got two knees in each leg!
And two elbows in each arm. I think it’s got a...a deformity of some kind.
Or a disease. Leprosy might cause something like this. Or polio.
FX: A MOANING SOUND - NOT QUITE HUMAN
(SHOCKED) Sylvia, look - it’s alive!
(URGENT) We should kill it.
Doctor Who -— A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 19 of 133
What?
It’s not one of us. Not British. I don’t know whether it’s a native or some kind of strange ape, but I think it’s dangerous. It might be infectious.
I don’t think leprosy can make a person look like this. It
looks more like the result of a car accident. You know what I mean —- bones broken and then reset badly. (DECISIVE) I think Elizabeth needs to take a look at it.
Are you mad?
(DEFIANT) it may not. be British, but we are... Lf we just left it here we’d be no better than the Mau Mau!
If we take it back we could be signing our own death warrants.
Surely we’re better than that. We have a responsibility to look after the sick and injured.
(UNHAPPY) All right. All right. (THINKS) Get me some branches while I pull down some vines.
What are you going to do?
If you intend pressing ahead with this lunacy then the least I can do is help make a stretcher. This... thing may be small, but it’s still going to be an effort getting it
back to the house.
FX: FADE FROM THE RAINFOREST
FX: TIME PASSES
Doctor Who — A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 20 of 133
SCENE 5: A BEDROOM
FX: MOANING AGAIN

Well it’s not a native, that’s for sure. You can get quite a variation in African tribes, from pygmies like the Biaka or the Twa to extremely tall and thin like the Watusi, but I’ve never heard of anything like this before. And the joints are natural, not the result of a deformity or an illness.
We thought it might be an animal of some kind. A previously undiscovered species.

Possible, I suppose. (BEAT) The fingers are long, indicating some kind of arboreal heritage. And it has an opposable thumb. (BEAT) No, make that two opposable thumbs. How very odd. (BEAT) The crainial development indicates a large brain. If it’s an ape then it’s somewhere up at the chimpanzee or gorilla level, rather than a new type of marmoset.
We can’t keep calling it
at
We need to give it a name.
Oh how twee. You’ll be knitting it clothes next.
Abraham. Abe the Ape.
(QUIET) Dear god preserve us.
Interesting.
(FX: THE SOUND OF WATER SPLASHING IN A BOWL, THEN A SPONGE
USED AGAINST SKIN)
This blood on its skin is coming from these scratches. Hundred of them. Thousands. Tiny scratches, all over its
body.
Doctor Who - A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 21 of 133
Knife scratches?
Too small.
Was it tortured?
Too many questions and not enough answers. (BEAT) It’s asleep now. Let it rest. I’11 make a full examination later.
I think we ought to tie it to the bed.
Don’t be silly. It’s barely larger than a child.
Denise, see if you can find a key to fit the lock on this bedroom door. At least we can stop it wandering around the house when it wakes up. I think -
FX: DISTANT KNOCKING ON THE FRONT DOOR OF THE HOUSE
What in Heaven’s name is that?
Someone’s at the door.
It can’t be Lucy - she’s still in the drawing room, writing her letter.
And as far as I know, Christine is still asleep in her room.
(WHISPERS) Is it... the Mau Mau?
Doctor Who — A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 22 of 133
If it is, they’re displaying considerably more politeness than I would have expected of them.
(FX: MORE KNOCKING. IT MIGHT OCCUR TO US THAT IT SOUNDS LIKE THE HANDLE OF AN UMBRELLA HITTING THE WOODEN DOOR)
Well - shall we answer it?
Denise - bring the rifle.
(FX: THE THREE WOMEN LEAVE THE BEDROOM AND WALK DOWN THE STAIRS)
FADE OUT
Doctor Who -— A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 23 of 133
SCENE 6: THE HALL
(AT THE BOTTOM OF THE STAIRS, BUT GETTING LOUDER AS THEY APPROACH) Is it the Army? Are we rescued?
Stand back. Denise are you ready?
Just about.
FX: THE DOOR OPENS
THE DOCTOR Good afternoon, ladies. Might I borrow a cup of sugar?
Who is it? I can’t see.
It’s a white man in a linen suit. And he’s got an umbrella!
Are you from the British Government?
THE DOCTOR Were you expecting someone?
We were rather hoping for the Army.
Or the Diplomatic Corps.
Or even a decent pastry chef.
THE DOCTOR I’m sorry to disappoint you. May I come in?
Oh, where are our manners? Yes, please do come in.
FX: THE DOCTOR ENTERS THE HALL
Doctor Who — A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 24 of 133
THE DOCTOR I am the Doctor.
We already have a doctor. (BEAT) Where’s Elizabeth? She was here a moment ago.
I think she popped back upstairs. (BEAT) I’m Lucy, by the way. Lucy Watts.
Sylvia O’Donnell.
Denise Waterford.
THE DOCTOR Charmed to meet you. And what a lovely place you have here. You can stop pointing that rifle at me, by the way.
Oh, pardon me. I forgot I was holding it.
THE DOCTOR Is it just the four of you here?
Christine is asleep upstairs. Christine MacCormack.
And there’s Abraham.
(INTERRUPTING) What’s the news from England?
Are the Army coming?
How much of the country do the Mau Mau control?
Doctor Who — A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 25 of 133
THE DOCTOR (TO HIMSELF) The Mau Mau Uprising? Kenya, 1950s. Yes, of course! (TO THE WOMEN) I’m pleased to be able to tell you

that the British Government is pursuing a diplomatic solution through dialogue with the rebel spokesman, Jomo Kenyatta. The worst of the fighting is over, but I fear that the country you knew is gone forever. Self-rule is the inevitable outcome.
Ridiculous. The natives can’t govern themselves. They can barely grow enough food to keep themselves alive, and the
different tribes are always at each others’ throats.
Would you like a cup of tea?
THE DOCTOR
That would be exceptionally kind. (TO HIMSELF) From rifles to tea in less than a minute. That’s a record, even for me.
How exactly did you get here? We would have heard a car.
THE DOCTOR Oh, I have my own transport.
One man, parachuted alone into the dark heart of Africa to reach an accommodation with the rebellious natives. How romantic.
How foolhardy.
Are you alone?
THE DOCTOR For the nonce. Why do you ask?
We found someone in the rainforest earlier. They were... injured
THE DOCTOR How very interesting. It does sound like something that would generally happen to any companion of mine, but for now I’m traveling by myself.
Doctor Klein thinks that the person we found is deformed in
some way.
BEAT
THE DOCTOR
GRIMLY
Doctor Who -— A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 26 of 133
Doctor Klein?
Yes, do you know her?
THE DOCTOR
Blonde,
blue eyed and strikingly attractive? Hint of a
German accent?
Yes.
THE DOCTOR I believe our paths have crossed.
How lovely.
THE DOCTOR
SERIOUS NOW
inter]
loper.
as wel
Ll.
I think it’s time I met this strange And the creature you found in the rainforest
FX: FADE OUT
Doctor Who - A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 27 of 133
SCENE 7: A BEDROOM
FX: MOANING AS THE CREATURE STIRS
FX: A SOFT KNOCKING ON THE DOOR
THE DOCTOR (OUTSIDE) Hello?
FX: THE DOOR OPENS
THE DOCTOR
Well well well, what do we have here. You’re not from this planet, are you my friend? Two joints in each limb, reticulated skin, and those eyes. You have possibly the
saddest eyes I have ever seen.
I concur. Apart from the bit about the eyes. That’s just poetic licence.
THE DOCTOR Doctor Klein, I presume. Please, don’t stay in the shadows. Come into the light.
(ALMOST IN AWE) I had a feeling we would meet again, somewhere, somehow. At first it was a certainty, then a hope, then just a dream.
THE DOCTOR Oh, I never had any doubt about it.
(STILL DREAMILY) That was your TARDIS I heard earlier! I thought I was imagining things.
THE DOCTOR Still lusting after it so that you can go back and change history?
(GETS A GRIP ON HERSELF) Change it back, you mean.
THE DOCTOR You still believe that your reality is the right one, and this one is some kind of monstrous mistake?
Doctor Who - A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 28 of 133

I remember a world that doesn’t exist, and never will. I remember people who have never been born. Sometimes I think I’m going mad. Other times I think you’re the one who’s insane. You must be insane to believe you have to right to just reorder reality the way you want.
THE DOCTOR Not the way I want. The way it should be.
BEAT
No Miss McShane this time around? I’m sure I would have heard her by now, if she was here.
THE DOCTOR
I’m traveling on my own now. And what about you - where have you been hiding yourself away since our last encounter?
After the war ended in that farcical victory for Britain I escaped to South America. There’s quite a little colony of National Socialists down there. A home away from home.
THE DOCTOR
Yes, I remember bumping into one of them. Mister De Flores, I believe. He was just as fanatical as you. It must be something in the water down there.
(REMINISCING) Ah, Hans. He was always the Fuhrer’s favourite. I hope that one day, when the Fourth Reich emerges to take its rightful place leading the world, Hans will be the new Fuhrer.
THE DOCTOR And will he-make ‘the trains: run on. time?
You say that as if it’s a bad thing to have a predictable transport system.
Doctor Who —- A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 29 of 133
THE DOCTOR That rather depends on how you make the trains run on time, and what happens to the drivers who are late.
I’m not going to be distracted by simplistic moralising. You believe this creature to be from the stars?
THE DOCTOR It’s not native to Earth, I know that much. I don’t recognize the species, however.
So the double joints and the colour of its skin are natural.
THE DOCTOR
As far as I can tell. But these scratches all over its body concern me. I presume you didn’t make them yourself in some despicable attempt to extract information from it
Scratches as shallow as this are no use in interrogations...
THE DOCTOR
(MURMURS) I bow to your superior expertise
And I can’t see how they could have been caused in a fight. They would have been much deeper and more savage.
THE DOCTOR Which leaves..?

The best theory I can come up with is that the creature ran through a thorn bush, and scratched itself badly. I would have given it a tetanus shot and some antibiotics, but if it really does come from the stars then I might just end up poisoning it.
THE DOCTOR That’s very Hippocratic of you.
Doctor Who — A Thousand Tiny Wings / Page 30 of 133
Whatever you may think of us, Doctor, the National Socialists were never barbarians. We did what we did for the betterment of the human race.
THE DOCTOR

(ANGRY) And when Doctor Mengele gave twins the same dose of poison in order to see whether they would take the same amount of time to die, was that justified? Did that add to the sum of human knowledge?
(TIRED) Doctor Mengele had only the best motives, but his methods were... questionable. Even the Fuhrer came to
acknowledge that. But you shouldn’t tar the entire Third
Reich with the actions of just one man. Would you like me to list all the British and American researchers who have
committed abuses against their fellow man?
